History of Present Illness:
___ PMH HTN, CKD, PPM who was transferred from ___ 
___ with cholecystitis. She presented with weakness, 
abdominal pain and emesis. A non-con CT was done given her CKD 
and showed concern for cholelithiasis/choledocholithiasis. An 
ultrasound also showed cholelithiasis. She was noted to be 
hypotensive to 86/50 so was given 3L IVF with improvement in her 
SBP to 110s. She was intermittently tachycardic to 130s in AF so 
she was given amiodarone. She was also given cipro/flagyl ___ 
to transfer. She was transferred to ___ for advanced endoscopy 
and ICU level care. 

On arrival to the ___ ED her vital signs were 98.3 110 110/50 
20 97% RA. She was given one dose of pip-tazo. Surgery and ERCP 
were both consulted. ERCP plans to do an ERCP AM of ___. VS 
___ to transfer were 83 106/47 16 100% RA.

On arrival to the ICU she says she is feeling much better. She 
had been having nausea and emesis at home but says this has now 
resolved. She also denies any abdominal pain.

- HTN
- CKD
- Atrial fibrillation
- Kidney stones

Brief Hospital Course:
Mrs ___ is a ___ year old woman with a 
history of HTN, CKD, PPM who was transferred from ___ 
___ with abnormal LFTs and concern for 
cholecystitis/cholangitis vs acute pancreatitis. 

# Pancreatitis vs cholangitis/cholecystitis: Patient was 
transferred for concerns of cholecystitis/cholangitis, OSH 
imaging demonstrated dilated CBD of 10mm and suggestion of 
possible choledocholithiasis on OSH CT. ON admission, surgery 
was consulted who felt her presentation to be more consistent 
with gallstone pancreatitis with a stone that had since passed 
given improvement in her symptoms at time of transfer. She was 
initially treated with cipro/flagyl and completed a seven day 
course which ended on ___. Advanced endoscopy performed 
an ERCP on ___ which demonstrated a 9mm stone that was 
removed, and a sphincterotomy performed. LFTs trended down and 
had normalized ___ to discharge, with exception of AP which 
remained slightly elevated. Patient was treated with 
conservative pancreatitis management and by day of discharge, 
she was tolerating a regular diet without pain and having bowel 
movements. Surgery was consulted for possible cholecystectomy, 
but patient was not interested in undergoing cholecystectomy. 
Surgery felt that given she had a sphincterotomy, was on 
systemic anticoagulation, and given her age and over all risk 
factors for surgery that this was a reasonable approach. 

# Atrial Fibrillation
# Bradycardia: Patient experienced bradycardia to ___ on the 
day of her ERCP, thought to be a vagal event, with no pacemaker 
activity at the time of her event.  Electrophysiology was 
consulted and and felt this was a vagal episode given her 
history of atrial fibrillation and use of beta-blocker. On 
pacemaker interrogation, it was assessed to be at the end of its 
known lifespan based on the time of implant and its model 
number. Underwent an uncomplicated generator exchange on ___ 
and was discharged with post-operative antibiotics and intent to 
___ at ___ on ___. Given the 
note of her atrial fibrillation, clopidogrel was stopped and 
apixaban was started as it is a more beneficial medication in 
reducing stroke complications in patients with atrial 
fibrillation after consultation with electrophysiology.  Plavix 
was not continued as there was no history of recent ACS or 
coronary or peripheral intervention requiring antiplatelet agent 
and there would be an increased risk of bleeding with a dual 
combination of Plavix and apixaban. The risks and benefits of 
systemic anticoagulation were discussed with patient by MD 
___ course. Apixaban prescription for 60 tablets of 2.5 
mg twice daily prescribed at discharge. Selection of low dose 
chosen given her age greater than ___ years and low BMI.

# HTN: Held home diuretics including Lasix and spironolactone in 
the setting of fasting for GI procedures. Given stable 
oxygenation and lack of any hypervolemia for many days Lasix and 
spironolactone were not resumed on discharge but can be assessed 
at the next outpatient ___

# CKD: Unclear baseline Creatinine, but Cr improved to 1.0

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
[ ] discharged with cephalexin TID for 4 days post-PPM generator 
exchange
[ ] ___ in cardiology device clinic for PPM check at ___ 
on ___
[ ] check LFTs, and alkaline phosphatase at next clinic 
appointment to ensure resolution. 
[ ] started on low dose apixaban 2.5mg BID for atrial

anticoagulation with patient.

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___,

You were hospitalized for gallstone pancreatitis which improved 
with supportive care including antibiotics bowel rest and IV 
fluids. With conservative treatment, you were able to take a 
regular diet. The GI team performed a procedure called an ERCP 
on ___ to open up your bile ducts and help the passage of 
the and any future gallstones. 

Usually, in these circumstances we would preform a surgery to 
remove your gallbladder to prevent the recurrence of future 
gallstones, but you informed us that you were not interested in 
undergoing surgery including cholecystectomy given your concerns 
regarding anesthesia and related surgical risks.  We shared with 
you that sometimes cholecystectomy is performed to reduce risk 
of future gallstone complications given her age and other 
medical problems including use of anticoagulation this is a fair 
decision.

We found that your pacemaker battery was at the end of its life 
span and electrophysiology  performed generator change on 
___. You tolerated this procedure well. 

___ APPOINTMENTS
- You will need to ___ in the cardiology department device 
clinic in one week (see below) to check your pacemaker)
- You will need to call your primary care doctor to schedule an 
appointment soon after you leave the hospital.

MEDICATION CHANGES
- We adjusted your anticoagulation to now be use of apixaban 2.5 
mg twice a day which is a new medication for you for the 
purposes of reducing stroke related to chronic atrial 
fibrillation.  This medication works differently than Plavix.
- We advised you to STOP Plavix and only take apixaban at this 
time.
- You need to take an antibiotic called Keflex (cephalexin) for 
a few days after you leave the hospital to protect against 
infection at your pacemaker site. 

Please inform any physicians or surgeons that you are taking a 
blood thinner for atrial fibrillation before you go for any 
invasive procedures as there is at increased risk of bleeding 
with this medication.  Do not stop apixaban on your own without 
informing her cardiologist or primary care physician.  Report 
any bleeding bruising weakness to your doctor right away as this 
may be a sign of internal bleeding related to apixaban and blood 
test should be performed.

Please take all medications as prescribed and keep all scheduled 
doctor's appointments. Seek medical attention if you develop a 
worsening or recurrence of the same symptoms that originally 
brought you to the hospital, experience any of the warning signs 
listed below, or have any other symptoms that concern you.

It was a pleasure taking care of you!
Your ___ Care Team

 
Followup Instructions:
___

qafib.question: Does the note describe the patient as having permanent, paroxysmal, or persistent afib?

qprior_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having a stroke or transient ischemic attack?

qarterial_hypertension.question: Does the note describe the patient as having arterial hypertension on treatment (high bp e.g. >140, or HTN)?

qt2d.question: Does the note describe the patient as having Diabetes mellitus (DM1, DM2, T2D, T1DM, T2DM)?

qheart_failure.question: Does the note describe the patient as having heart failure?

qsurgical_valvular_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having valvular disease requiring surgery (stenosis)?

qafib_ablation.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a planned or past ablation procedure for afib?

qbleeding.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a serious bleeding in the past 6 months?

qpeptic_ulcer_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having peptic ulcer disease?

qrecent_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a stroke during this admission or within the last month? (Answer yes for any recent stroke if the date is unclear)

qhemorrhagic.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having any hemorrhagic tendencies or blood dyscrasias?

qbipolar.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with bipolar disorder?

qschizophrenia.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with schizophrenia or any schizoaffective disorders?

qmdd.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with depression or major depressive disorder (MDD)?

qmed_decisions.question: Does the note describe the patient as being unable to make medical decisions? (Answer no unless there is evidence the patient cannot make their own medical decisions).

qchads2.question: What is the highest CHADS2 score mentioned? Answer "NA" if no CHADS2 score is in the note.

qblood_glucose.question: What is the highest blood glucose lab mentioned? Answer "NA" if no blood glucose score is in the note.

qlvef.question: What is the lowest left ventricular ejection (LVEF, ef, ejection fraction) fraction mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no LVEF is in the note, Answer 55 if the lowest value is 55% or greater.

qPLT.question: What is the lowest platelet count (PLT) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no platelet count is available in the note.

qHGB.question: What is the lowest hemoglobin (HGB) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no HGB value is available in the note.

qCREAT.question: What is the higest serum creatinine (Creat) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no creatinine value is available in the note.

qAST.question: What is the higest aspartate aminotransferase level (AST) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no AST value is available in the note.

qBILI.question: What is the higest total bilirubin (TotBili, Bili) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no bilirubin value is available in the note.
